The TCP port on which your mail server accepts connections (usually 25).
The host name or address of the SMTP server to send mail messages through.
Enables or disables the email logging options.
Specify the type of security protocol that should be used on the connection: 0 - None 1 - STARTTLS, if available 2 - STARTTLS 3 - SSL/TLS
The email address to receive informational messages.
The email address to receive notices.
The email address to receive warnings.
The email address to receive error messages.
The email address to receive emergency messages.
The email address to receive critical messages.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: EmailEmergency : emergency@test.com EmailServer : smtp.test.host EmailInfo : EmailNotice : EmailEnable : yes EmailPort : 25 EmailSSLMode : 3 EmailDomain : test.com EmailError : EmailPassword : ******** EmailWarn : EmailCritical : critical@test.com EmailUser :

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you set which hosts the various Syslog messages get sent to.
Allows you set which hosts the various Syslog messages get sent to.
Specifies the syslog host for critical notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for emergency notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for error notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for information notices.
Specifies the syslog host for general notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for warning notifications.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Specifies the syslog host for critical notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for emergency notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for error notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for information notices.
Specifies the syslog host for general notifications.
Specifies the syslog host for warning notifications.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

maml:alert.maml:para: Up to ten individual IP addresses/hostnames can be specified for each of the Syslog fields. Multiple IP addresses/hostnames must be differentiated using a comma-separated list.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: SyslogInfo : 20.11.0.191 SyslogCritical : 20.11.0.190 SyslogNotice : 20.11.0.192 SyslogEmergency : 20.11.0.190 SyslogWarn : 20.11.0.193 SyslogError : 20.11.0.191

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to set the values of Networking options.
Allows you to set the values of Networking options.
Enabling this options allows the LoadMaster to NAT connections from the Real Servers to the internet.
The LoadMaster has been optimized with HTTP workloads in mind. Enabling this option allows non HTTP uploads to work correctly.
Specify, in seconds, the time a connection can be idle before it is closed. This is independent of Persistency Timeout. Setting a value of 0 resets to the default value of 660 seconds.

By default, the system uses TCP keepalives to check for failed clients. Enabling this option improves the reliability of older TCP connections (SSH sessions). Not normally required for normal HTTP/HTTPS services.
Use this option to enable the ability to move the default gateway to a different interface.
Enable this option to allow assigning non-local Real Servers to Virtual Services.
Enable this option to force traffic from Virtual Services, which have default route entries set, to be routed to the interface where the Virtual Service’s default route is located.
When enabled, the LoadMaster will close its connection to the Real Servers by using TCP RESET instead of the normal close handshake.

When transparency is disabled for a Virtual Service, the source IP address of connections to Real Servers is the Virtual Service. When enabled, the source IP address is the local address of the LoadMaster. If the Real Server is on a subnet, the subnet address of the LoadMaster will be used.

When transparency is disabled for a Virtual Service, the source IP address of connections to Real Servers is the Virtual Service. When enabled, the source IP address is the local address of the LoadMaster. If the Real Server is on a subnet, the subnet address of the LoadMaster will be used.
The LoadMaster can include a timestamp in the SYN when connecting to Real Servers. Only enable this option when requested to from KEMP Support.
When enabled, this option only accepts IP frames from a host over the interface where the routing algorithm would route frames to the host. This is known as strict source route validation.
Select the strength of the key used in the Diffe-Hellman key exchanges. If this value is changed, a reboot is required in order to use the new value. The default value is 2048 Bits.
This option allows clients to specify the HTTP(S) proxy server and port the LoadMaster will use to access the internet.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Enabling this options allows the LoadMaster to NAT connections from the Real Servers to the internet.
The LoadMaster has been optimized with HTTP workloads in mind. Enabling this option allows non HTTP uploads to work correctly.
Specify, in seconds, the time a connection can be idle before it is closed. This is independent of Persistency Timeout. Setting a value of 0 resets to the default value of 660 seconds.

By default, the system uses TCP keepalives to check for failed clients. Enabling this option improves the reliability of older TCP connections (SSH sessions). Not normally required for normal HTTP/HTTPS services.
Use this option to enable the ability to move the default gateway to a different interface.
Enable this option to allow assigning non-local Real Servers to Virtual Services.
Enable this option to force traffic from Virtual Services, which have default route entries set, to be routed to the interface where the Virtual Service’s default route is located.
When enabled, the LoadMaster will close its connection to the Real Servers by using TCP RESET instead of the normal close handshake.

When transparency is disabled for a Virtual Service, the source IP address of connections to Real Servers is the Virtual Service. When enabled, the source IP address is the local address of the LoadMaster. If the Real Server is on a subnet, the subnet address of the LoadMaster will be used.

When transparency is disabled for a Virtual Service, the source IP address of connections to Real Servers is the Virtual Service. When enabled, the source IP address is the local address of the LoadMaster. If the Real Server is on a subnet, the subnet address of the LoadMaster will be used.
The LoadMaster can include a timestamp in the SYN when connecting to Real Servers. Only enable this option when requested to from KEMP Support.
When enabled, this option only accepts IP frames from a host over the interface where the routing algorithm would route frames to the host. This is known as strict source route validation.
Select the strength of the key used in the Diffe-Hellman key exchanges. If this value is changed, a reboot is required in order to use the new value. The default value is 2048 Bits.
This option allows clients to specify the HTTP(S) proxy server and port the LoadMaster will use to access the internet.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

maml:alert.maml:para: This is a legacy command and cannot be used to set all of the available parameters. Please refer to the Get-Help of the Set-Parameter command to view a full list of parameters that can be configured.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: subnetoriginating : yes resetclose : no http_proxy : example3.com multigw : yes subnetorigin : yes dhkeysize : 2048 nonlocalrs : no conntimeout : 1000 tcptimestamp : no snat : yes keepalive : yes allowupload : yes routefilter : no onlydefaultroutes : no

Specify the SNMP community string.
Specify the username.
Specify the user password.
Specify the relevant authentication protocol: - MD5 - SHA
SHA is a more secure protocol. Note: These values are case sensitive - please enter them in uppercase.
Specify the relevant privacy protocol: - DES - AES
AES is a more secure protocol. Note: These values are case sensitive - please enter them in uppercase.
Specify the contact address that is sent in SNMP responses.
Enable or disable SNMP.
Enable SNMP V3. 0 - Disabled 1 - Enabled
Enable the generation of SNMP events whenever a significant event occurs.
Specify the sink address for SNMP type 1 traps.
Specify the sink address for SNMP type 2 traps.
Send SNMP traps from the shared IP address. This option is only available when the LoadMaster is in HA mode.
Specify the list of machines that can access the SNMP subsystem. If no clients are specified, then anyone can access SNMP.
Specify the location that is sent in SNMP responses.

Allows you to set permissions for local user.
Allows you to set permissions for local user.
Username of the relevant user.
The valid values for this parameter and their descriptions are below:

real - This role permits enabling and disabling Real Servers. Users with the Real Servers permission cannot add SubVSs. vs - This role permits managing Virtual Services. This includes SubVSs. Virtual Service modifications permitted include add, delete and modify for any subnet. rules - This role permits managing Rules. Rule modifications permitted include add, delete and modify. backup - This role permits performing system backups. certs - This role permits managing SSL Certificates. Certificate management includes adding, deleting and modifying SSL Certificates. cert3 - This role permits managing intermediate Certificates. Certificate management includes the ability to add and delete intermediate certificates. certbackup - This role permits the ability to export and import certificates. users - This role is allowed access to all functionality within the System Configuration > System Administration > User Management WUI screen. root - This role gives users all permissions except the permission to change the bal password and the permission to create or delete other users. geo - This role is used only with the LoadMaster GEO product. For more information on GEO and the Global Server Load Balancing (GSLB) Feature Pack, refer to the GEO, Product Overview.
To set the permissions to none, leave the parameter blank, for example &perms=

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Rule modifications permitted include add, delete and modify. backup - This role permits performing system backups. certs - This role permits managing SSL Certificates. Certificate management includes adding, deleting and modifying SSL Certificates. cert3 - This role permits managing intermediate Certificates. Certificate management includes the ability to add and delete intermediate certificates. certbackup - This role permits the ability to export and import certificates. users - This role is allowed access to all functionality within the System Configuration > System Administration > User Management WUI screen. root - This role gives users all permissions except the permission to change the bal password and the permission to create or delete other users. geo - This role is used only with the LoadMaster GEO product. For more information on GEO and the Global Server Load Balancing (GSLB) Feature Pack, refer to the GEO, Product Overview.
To set the permissions to none, leave the parameter blank, for example &perms=

Enables or disables hover help in the web user interface.

Sets the Message Of The Day (MOTD) for the web user interface. Either plain text or a text file can be used. The maximum number of characters is 5,000. An error will be displayed if the MOTD is greater than 5,000 characters.
Enables or disables session control.
Specifies the number of seconds that the WUI can be idle before logging the user out. This can be set from 60 to 86400 seconds.
Number of failed attempts before locking the user account. This can be set from 1 to 999.
Specifies the number of display lines in the web user interface. This can be set from 10 to 100.

The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

maml:alert.maml:para: This is a legacy command and cannot be used to set all of the available parameters. Please refer to the Get-Help of the Set-Parameter command to view a full list of parameters that can be configured.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: sessioncontrol : yes sessionidletime : 70 sessionmaxfailattempts : 0 motd : Test Message hoverhelp : yes wuidisplaylines : 0

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to set Single Sign-On (SSO) Domain options.
Allows you to set Single Sign-On (SSO) Domain options.
Specifies the name of the SSO domain LoadMaster entry to be modified.
Specifies the encryption to use for authentication. This parameter accepts "Unencrypted", "StartTLS", and "LDAPS".
Specifies the server(s) to authenticate against.
When using dual factor authentication, use the server parameter to set the address of the RADIUS server(s) and use the server2 parameter to set the address of the LDAP server(s).

Specify the transport protocol used to communicate with the authentication server. Possible values are: - LDAP-Unencrypted - LDAP-StartTLS - LDAP-LDAPS - RADIUS - RSA-SECURID - Certificate - KCD - RADIUS and LDAP-Unencrypted - RADIUS and LDAP-StartTLS - RADIUS and LDAP-LDAPS
The maximum number of failed login attempts before the user is locked out. Range: 0 – 999 0 = Never lock out

The time that must elapse before the max_failed_auths counter is reset to 0. This must be less than the unblocktout value. This parameter is only relevant if the max_failed_auths parameter is set to a value greater than 0. Range: 60-86400
The timeout in seconds before a blocked account is automatically unblocked again. This must be greater than the reset_fail_tout parameter value. Range: 60-86400

Specify the logon string format used to authenticate to the LDAP/RADIUS server. The Username%20only value is only available if the auth_type is set to a RADIUS or RSA-SecurID protocol. The Username value is not available if the auth_type is set to RADIUS or a RADIUS and LDAP protocol.
Specify the logon string format used to authenticate to the server.
The login domain to be used. This is also used with the logon format to construct the normalized username, for example: - Principalname: <username>@<domain> - Username: <domain>\<username>
Specify the type of session timeout to be used: - idle time - max duration
The session idle timeout value in seconds. This value is used in a public environment. Range: 60-68400
The maximum duration timeout value for the session in seconds. This value is used in a public environment. Range: 60-86400
The session idle timeout value in seconds. This value is used in a private environment. Range: 60-68400
The maximum duration timeout value for the session in seconds. This value is used in a private environment. Range: 60-86400
The username that will be used to check the authentication server(s).
The password of the user that will be used to check the authentication server(s).
The shared secret to be used between the radius server and the LoadMaster.
The name of the Kerberos realm.
The name of the Kerberos Key Distribution Center (KDC).
The username of the Kerberos trusted user.
The password of the Kerberos trusted user.
The LDAP administrator username. This is only relevant when the authtype is set to Certificate.
The LDAP administrator password. This is only relevant when the authtype is set to Certificate.
Specify if this is an outbound KCD SSO domain or not. y – KCD n – Not KCD

This option is only available when the authtype is set to Certificate. When this option is enabled - in addition to checking the validity of the client certificate, the client certificate will also be checked against the altSecurityIdentities (ASI) attribute of the user on the Active Directory.
Enabling this parameter allows a fallback to check the Common Name (CN) in the certificate when the SAN is not available.
Enable or disable the transcode of logon credentials from ISO-8859-1 to UTF-8, when required. 0 - Disable 1 - Enable

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: Id : 1 Name : EXAMPLE.COM server : 10.151.11.80 testuser : test1@example.com ldap_version : 3 server_side : 0 auth_type : LDAP-StartTLS logon_fmt : Principalname logon_transcode : 0 logon_domain : example.com kerberos_domain : kerberos_kdc : kcd_username : admin max_failed_auths : 0 reset_fail_tout : 60 unblock_tout : 1800 sess_tout_type : idle time sess_tout_idle_pub : 900 sess_tout_duration_pub : 1800 sess_tout_idle_priv : 900 sess_tout_duration_priv : 28800 cert_check_asi : 0

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to unblock users which are currently blocked from accessing the SSO domain.
Allows you to unblock users which are currently blocked from accessing the SSO domain.
The name of the SSO domain.
The username of the user to be unblocked.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
The name of the SSO domain.
The username of the user to be unblocked.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Create or modify a custom cipher set.

Updates an existing custom cipher set or creates a new custom cipher set. If the name of an existing custom cipher set is used, that cipher set will be updated. If a new name is used, a new cipher set will be created.
The name of the custom cipher set.
A colon (:) separated list of ciphers to assign to the set.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
Specifies the network port that is used to connect to the load balancer. The default port is 443 because the load balancer is configured to use HTTPS.
The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. If you attempt to use the web interface, you will need to specify the new port number in the URI to access the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a user name, such as "User01", "Domain01\User01", or user@contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.

The session user credentials are stored in the $cred preference variable. You can change the session credentials by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet with the -Credential parameter. If the session credential is not set or the -Credential parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
The name of the custom cipher set.
A colon (:) separated list of ciphers to assign to the set.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
Specifies the network port that is used to connect to the load balancer. The default port is 443 because the load balancer is configured to use HTTPS.
The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. If you attempt to use the web interface, you will need to specify the new port number in the URI to access the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a user name, such as "User01", "Domain01\User01", or user@contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.

The session user credentials are stored in the $cred preference variable. You can change the session credentials by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet with the -Credential parameter. If the session credential is not set or the -Credential parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

maml:alert.maml:para: If the name of an existing custom cipher set is specified, that cipher set will be updated. If a new name is used, a new cipher set will be created.

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to configure the HSM settings.
Allows you to configure the HSM settings.
To set the HSM sub-system to Safenet Luna HSM use LunaCA3. To set the HSM sub-system to Cavium HSM use cavhsm. These parameters are case sensitive.
Specify the address of the Safenet HSM unit to be used.
Specify the password for the partition on the HSM so that the LoadMaster can access the HSM.
Enable or disable Safenet HSM: 0 – Disabled 1 – Enabled
Specify the address of the Cavium HSM unit to be used.

The password for the HSM partition. The HSM partition password would have been set on the HSM when originally configuring the partition. For further information, please consult the HSM vendor documentation.
The username for the HSM partition.
Enable Cavium HSM.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
To set the HSM sub-system to Safenet Luna HSM use LunaCA3. To set the HSM sub-system to Cavium HSM use cavhsm. These parameters are case sensitive.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

maml:alert.maml:para: Starting the HSM may take some time.

Disabling the HSM will cause the LoadMaster to be unable to create new SSL (HTTPS) connections and will immediately drop existing connections until another HSM is added or the certificate configuration is changed.
It is strongly recommended to only change the HSM configuration when there are no active SSL connections.

dev:remarks.maml:para: Example Output: engine enable addr ------ ------ ---- LunaCA3 0 10.11.0.14

maml:description.maml:para: Allows you to enable or disable the automatic download of AFP commercial rule file updates.

Allows you to enable or disable the automatic download of AFP commercial rule file updates. When this option is enabled, updated rules are downloaded on a daily basis from KEMP. The default installation time for these rule updates is 4am. The time at which the installation of these rule file updates can be set by running the SetWafInstallTime command.
You can see what this is currently set to by running the GetWafSettings command.
Enable/disable automatic commercial rule file downloads. 0 - Disable 1 - Enable

maml:description.maml:para: Configure the Web Application Firewall (WAF) auto-update settings.

Enable or disable the automatic installation of updated commercial rule files.

Set the time of day that the commercial rule files will be automatically installed. The hour is the hour value from the 24-hour clock (0-23), for example 13 is 1pm. The range is 0-23. Minutes cannot be specified.

maml:description.maml:para: Update the LoadMaster's license using the offline method.

A BLOB is required to license a LoadMaster using the offline method. BLOBs are emailed to customers when requested. The BLOB is the body of text from the word begin to the word end in the email. Copy and paste this text into a text file. This file must be uploaded when running this command in order to successfully license the LoadMaster.
The local path to the license file to upload. Use the Get-AccessKey command to get the key to use to generate a license from KEMP Technologies. This parameter is required.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Force a new resolution of DNS names.

The LoadMaster will try to resolve the DNS names: • If the address is not found, or if it is the same as before – nothing is done (except a log entry is generated). • If the address is different, the Real Server entry will be updated with the new address, if possible. • If the new address is invalid for some reason, for example if it is a non-local address and the Non-Local Real Servers setting has been disabled, no changes are made and a log is generated.

Adds a standalone interface to a bonded interface.

The Interface ID that should be bound to the Bonded Interface. To view the interface ID for each of the interfaces, run the Get-Statistics command. The interface ID is the first number displayed in each interface row.
The Bonded Interface ID that the network interface should be bound to.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Adds an address to the global black or white list.
Adds a host or network IP address to the global black or white Access Control List (ACL). Note that black and white lists are only enabled when packet filtering is enabled.
Specifies the access control list type: "black" or "white".
Specifies a host or network IP address to add to the access control list. The address can be specified in CIDR format. If the CIDR is not specified, the system uses a default of /32.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
Specifies the network port that is used to connect to the load balancer. The default port is 443 because the load balancer is configured to use HTTPS.
The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. If you attempt to use the web interface, you will need to specify the new port number in the URI to access the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a user name, such as "User01", "Domain01\User01", or user@contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.

The session user credentials are stored in the $cred preference variable. You can change the session credentials by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet with the -Credential parameter. If the session credential is not set or the -Credential parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

Specifies the Virtual Service port number.
Specifies the Virtual Service protocol: "tcp" or "udp".
Specify the type of list: - black: blocked addresses - white: allowed addresses Note: This is case sensitive – the type value should be in lowercase.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. A password to encrypt the certificate backup file. This password will be needed to restore the certificate file to the LoadMaster.

The local path where the certificate backup file should be saved. If no file is specified, the backup file will be saved as C:\Temp\CertificateBackup_yyyy-MM-dd_HH-mm-ss, assuming that C:\ is the System Root drive specified in the Environment variables.

maml:description.maml:para: Generates a template from an existing Virtual Service.

Retrieves the value of the Packet Routing Filter option.
Retrieves the value of the Packet Routing Filter option. This can also be used to determine whether packet filtering is enabled.
The following packet filtering options are supported: enable, drop or ifblock
The "enable" option indicates whether packet filtering is enabled or disabled on the LoadMaster. Note that packet filtering is enabled by default and cannot be disabled if the GEO feature is enabled.

If packet filtering is enabled, the "drop" option indicates whether the LoadMaster silently drops blocked packets or rejects them by responding with an ICMP reject packet. For security reasons it is usually best to drop any blocked packets silently.
If packet filtering is enabled, the "ifblock" option indicates whether the LoadMaster restricts network traffic by imposing restrictions upon routing between attached subnets.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

maml:description.maml:para: Create a new Sub-Virtual Service.
Creates a new Sub-Virtual Service by identifying the parent Virtual Service by its Virtual Service index.
The index number of the parent Virtual Service.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
Specifies the network port that is used to connect to the load balancer. The default port is 443 because the load balancer is configured to use HTTPS.
The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. If you attempt to use the web interface, you will need to specify the new port number in the URI to access the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to perform this action. The default is the current user. Type a user name, such as "User01", "Domain01\User01", or user@contoso.com. Or, enter a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a user name, you are prompted for a password.

The session user credentials are stored in the $cred preference variable. You can change the session credentials by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet with the -Credential parameter. If the session credential is not set or the -Credential parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes a bonded interface.
Removes a bonded interface.
The ID of the interface that has the bond.
The ID of the bonded interface to be removed.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Removes an address from the global black or white list.
Removes a host or network IP address from the global black or white access control list. Note that black and white lists are only enabled when packet filtering is enabled.
Specifies the access control list type: "black" or "white".
Specifies a host or network IP address to remove from the access control list. The address can be specified in CIDR format. If the CIDR is not specified, the system uses a default of /32.

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.
Specifies the network port that is used to connect to the load balancer. The default port is 443 because the load balancer is configured to use HTTPS.
The default port for each session is stored in the $LBAccessPort preference variable. The session port can be set using the Initialize-LoadBalancer cmdlet and specifying the $LBPort parameter.

To change the port on the load balancer, use the Set-RemoteAccess cmdlet and specify the WUIPort value. The load balancer must be restarted for this change to take effect. Once you change this parameter and reboot the load balancer, you will either have to specify the new port on each new cmdlet issued or set the new session port value. If you attempt to use the web interface, you will need to specify the new port number in the URI to access the load balancer.

Deletes a host IP address and host FQDN.
Deletes a host IP address and host FQDN.
Specify the IP address for the entry.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.
The port of the load balancer.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Removes an address from the black or white list for a Virtual Service.
Removes a host or network IP address from the black or white access control list for a specific Virtual Service. Note that black and white lists are only enabled when packet filtering is enabled.
Specifies the Virtual Service IP address.
Specifies the Virtual Service port number.
Specifies the Virtual Service protocol: "tcp" or "udp".
Specify the type of list: - black: blocked addresses - white: allowed addresses Note: This is case sensitive – the type value should be in lowercase.
Specifies a host or network IP address to remove from the access control list. The address can be specified in CIDR format. If the CIDR is not specified, the system uses a default of /32.

Allows you to set the other AWS HA options: health check port and partner address.
Allows you to set the other AWS HA options: health check port and partner address.
Address of the HA partner.
The port over which the health check is run. This needs to be the same on both the master and the slave units in order for HA to function correctly.

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.
Sets a packet filtering option.
Sets a packet filtering option. This can also be used to enable or disable packet filtering. Note that packet filtering cannot be disabled if the GEO feature is enabled.
The following packet filtering options are supported: enable, drop or ifblock
The "enable" option indicates whether packet filtering is enabled or disabled on the LoadMaster. Note that packet filtering is enabled by default and cannot be disabled if the GEO feature is enabled.

If packet filtering is enabled, the "drop" option indicates whether the LoadMaster silently drops blocked packets or rejects them by responding with an ICMP reject packet. For security reasons it is usually best to drop any blocked packets silently.
If packet filtering is enabled, the "ifblock" option indicates whether the LoadMaster restricts network traffic by imposing restrictions upon routing between attached subnets.
Specify whether to enable or disable the specified Option: 0 – Disabled 1 – Enabled

Specifies the name or address of the load balancer that you wish to control. The default value is the value of the $LoadBalancerAddress preference variable. If the preference variable is not set and this parameter is omitted, the command will fail.

Assigns a WAF rule to the specified Virtual Service.
Assigns a WAF rule to the specified Virtual Service.
The IP address of the relevant Virtual Service.
Specifies the port on which this Virtual Service accepts connections.
Specifies the communication protocol of the Virtual Service. Valid options are TCP or UDP.

Specify the name of the rule to be assigned. The rule name must be preceded with a letter/word and a forward slash. The letter used depends on the type of rule being added: - C or Custom - Z or ApplicationGeneric - A or ApplicationSpecific - G or Generic

The IP address of the KEMP LoadMaster that you are directing the command to. This can be set globally by using the Initialize-LoadBalancer command, but can be overridden on each individual command by using this parameter.

Specifies a user account that has permission to administer the load balancer. You can either enter a username for the load balancer or provide a PSCredential object, such as an object that is returned by the Get-Credential cmdlet. When you type a username, you are prompted for a password.

maml:alert.maml:para: The rule name must be preceded with the relevant letter/word and a forward slash. The letter/word used depends on the type of rule being assigned.
This is case sensitive. The letter/word needs to be in the correct case for the command to work.
• C or Custom • Z or ApplicationGeneric • A or ApplicationSpecific • G or Generic
Multiple rules can be assigned in the same command by separating them with a space.
An invalid rule error will display if the name of the rule is not entered correctly, if the preceding letter is incorrect, or if the does not exist in the LoadMaster.
